sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/tests/db/uti.message:
Matt/Bart  this comment is not specific to this review, but more about future re-factoring.

I don't like the pattern we use where for each endpoint we typically have 2 methods in this file that are nearly identical.
get_test_X  and post_get_test_X

I'd prefer the "post" method to live in the unit test itself, since probably that is the only place that will ever call post. (most other times we will bypass the API calls and directly add to the DB using a different method).
I'd prefer the "post_get_X" method to call the get_test_X and then do any post-specific alterations to it there.

We shouldn't have post_xxxx utility functions at all in my opinion.  This to me is test/domain specific and should reside in the general utils directory.

Generally I think we need a large cleanup in this file.  Most of this file could be generalized based on the objects they are trying to create and  should leverage the sysinv/objects to construct the dictionaries.

Would be good to explain the regression since I have to reload this context into my head. Change I0558ece92f8657c2f6294e07965c619eb7c8dfcf was the fix for the bug and changed the logic in configdrive.update_instance to use the instance.launched_at field with the CONF.force_config_drive option, meaning if the instance wasn't created with the user explicitly requesting a config drive, and the image doesn't require a config drive, and finally the config option is True and the instance is launching for the first time (really during build, rebuild/evacuate and unshelve). Once the server has been initially built, instance.launched_at will not be None. So the logic in configdrive.update_instance is saying the instance requires config drive if CONF.force_config_drive is True and the instance is being built for the first time, but after that it doesn't require a config drive based on the CONF.force_config_drive value.

The issue in bug 1827492 was that a VM was created on a host where CONF.force_config_drive=False initially, and then config on that host was changed to CONF.force_config_drive=True, and then the VM was rebooted and failed because the virt driver calls configdrive.required_by (which configdrive.update_instance also calls) and was returning True because CONF.force_config_drive=True but there was no config drive for the VM so the reboot failed.

Your bug 1835822 is the opposite case; the VM was created when CONF.force_config_drive=True so configdrive.update_instance set instance.config_drive=True when _update_instance_after_spawn called it, then the host changed to CONF.force_config_drive=False and on reboot...what? I'm not clear on that from the commit message. If initially instance.config_drive is set to True won't it "stick" across the host config changes because configdrive.required_by looks at instance.config_drive which would be True?

Looking at your bug report and the logic today in _update_instance_after_spawn:

    instance.launched_at = timeutils.utcnow()
    configdrive.update_instance(instance)

And configdrive.required_by:

    return (instance.config_drive or
            (CONF.force_config_drive and not instance.launched_at) or
            image_prop == fields.ConfigDrivePolicy.MANDATORY
            )

If at initial server build CONF.force_config_drive=True, required_by would still return False (ignoring the user and image specified config drive) because instance.launched_at is not None, so instance.config_drive will be False even though it was built on a host with CONF.force_config_drive=True, correct? And that's the regression.

This part of your bug report is confusing to me:

"this results in a vm that is spawned on a host with force_config_drive=True initally spawning
with a config drive but loosing it after a hard reboot."

That seems the opposite of what I said above. Is that part of the bug report incorrect?

> This part of your bug report is confusing to me:
 > 
 > "this results in a vm that is spawned on a host with
 > force_config_drive=True initally spawning
 > with a config drive but loosing it after a hard reboot."
 > 
 > That seems the opposite of what I said above. Is that part of the
 > bug report incorrect?

I think I get this now. If the configdrive.required_by returns True on initial create because CONF.force_config_drive=True and instance.launched_at=None, then the created instance has a config drive. But on reboot when the libvirt driver calls configdrive.required_by, it returns False regardless of CONF.force_config_drive=True because instance.launched_at is not None, so the instance is rebooted without a config drive in the guest.

I still think that's essentially moot though because it's asserting that when CONF.force_config_drive=True on initial created, the instance will be created with a config drive, but that's not true because instance.launched_at (today, before your fix) will not be None when configdrive.required_by is called, right?

today yes but that is precisely the behaviour that was changed by https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659703.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659703. which tries to fix
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1827492

alter the behavior so that the config drive would not be present after the vm was rebooted.

prior to that change if a vm was  boot with
CONF.force_config_drive=True 

then if  CONF.force_config_drive=False was set and the agent restarted new vm would not have config driver but old vm would keep there config drive.

this behavior change was intoduce by this line 

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659703/8/nova/virt/configdrive.py@169

required_by is called after setting instance.launched_at

therefor bool(instance.launched_at) is always True
and 
(CONF.force_config_drive and not instance.launched_at) 
is always false.
(CONF.force_config_drive and not instance.launched_at) =>
(CONF.force_config_drive and not True) => (CONF.force_config_drive and False) => False


the current code flow is

instance.launched_at = timeutils.utcnow()
configdrive.update_instance(instance)

this patch swap the order

configdrive.update_instance(instance)
instance.launched_at = timeutils.utcnow()

so the first time the instance is booted instance.launched_at is unset when required_by is invoked 


(CONF.force_config_drive and not instance.launched_at) =>
(CONF.force_config_drive and not False) => (CONF.force_config_drive and True) => CONF.force_config_drive 


and on the second after a reboot
instance.config_drive has been set so 

(instance.config_drive or
            (CONF.force_config_drive and not instance.launched_at) or
            image_prop == fields.ConfigDrivePolicy.MANDATORY
            )

so the value set in the instance take precedence.

with the current code as modifed by https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659703/8/nova/virt/configdrive.py@169
the only time instance.config_drive  was ever true was if it was set in teh api or in the image property.
the config value was never saved which is not the behavior we had before https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659703/8/nova/virt/configdrive.py@169

vmware_nsxlib/v3/core_resources.py.message: This uuid is transport node uuid
Is it expected to get tz only from the first host_switch?

i have discussed this issue with Frank and Vicky, we have a conclusion that for current solution, the first host switch (if existed ) is the one we need. if we support other feature in the future, we'll need host switch to add some tag to identify.
extra safety: if for any reason host_switch_spec is missing on the TN spec, this will end up raising with "NoneType has no attribute get"
host_switches should not be non by "constructions

logic looks good.
Only a simple question. In case the node has more than 1 hostswitch, does it make sense to consider the first, or is it better to fail?

If we're ok with always considering the first you can do:

try:
     return [ep.get('transport_zone_id') for ep in
              host_switches[0].get('transport_zone_endpoints', [])]
except IndexError:
     return []

otherwise your code looks good
for current solution, we suppose customer use one host switch at a time, for future support, we may need to add tag in host switch to identify which one is what we want.

tn['host_switch_spec'] seems a dict here while L914 indicates it's a list. 

And there are two verification styles used: L915 via a content check and L923 via an exception. Maybe stick to one of them, like:

if not tn.get('host_switch_spec') or not tn['host_switch_spec'].get('host_switches'):
    return []

and remove the IndexError exception below.

No need to check content repeatedly. 
"len(host_switches) < 1" has been checked by "not tn['host_switch_spec'].get('host_switches')"
"not host_switches[0].get('transport_zone_endpoints')" is not needed because you give "transport_zone_endpoints" a default value in L924.

These 3 lines can be deleted.

nodepool/driver/devnest/provider.py.message: Is there an option to reserve indefinitely?  I think that would be best since nodepool/zuul may hold on to the node for quite some time, and in the case of a hold, indefinitely.  Nodepool will be able to release the reservation in all cases, so we don't need to rely on the timeout.

While there is no such option to reserve indefinitely, there could be an option to reserve for ridiculously long period.

In devnest there is service responsible for cleanup. The lifecycle outisde of nodepool is as follows:


 1. Reservation of the node for X hours
 2a. If the node was forcefully reserved (there were no free nodes when the request was made) the node is going into reservation pending state and then to "reserved" state.
 2b. Node is in "reserved" state
 3. Release of the node when the job finishes (either Jenkins or Zuul)
 4. Node goes into "reprovisioning pending" state
 5. Some external provisioner is reinstalling OS and configuring node to become Jenkins and Zuul capable
 6. The node is brought to "online" state.

In some cases 4-5 is skipped but it's up to devnest reprovisioner to decide if node should be brought to online state right away or it should be fully reprovisioned.

This is a contract script that is now forbidden in neutron. I think we can make it work if moved to expand branch though, see below why I think we can do it safely.

This script does three separate things:
1 create a new binding_index attribute;
2 fill in existing binding models with new values;
3 enforce constraint.

The first item should be ok for expand branch. The only problem with it is that it's nullable=False, which means existing bindings would not fulfill the column requirement. But this would be ok if we also move step 2 to the same script, like we have it in this patch set.

The second step should also be ok for expand branch. It would fill in existing bindings with index values, and new bindings would get new values by virtue of autoincrement=True. Of course, there is a danger here that an old neutron-server will create a binding while we are populating the new attribute. For what I understand, autoincremented value may then clash with the migration script. If we move the migration code to expand, we better handle such errors gracefully (maybe retry a bunch of times, and handle bindings one network at a time.

The value of the third step is not clear to me, because we already have autoincrement=True that will give us the needed uniqueness of indexes. But if it's just for code strictness, we can also have it in expand without issues.

It means that old neutron-servers will still be able to overcommit dhcp agents to networks. The thing that I want to fix here is concurrency. If I have two hosts, host-a and host-b, each with a DHCP agent. If two subnets are added to one network (which is not hosted by any dhcp agents yet) concurrently, then there is a chance that this network will be hosted by two dhcp agents, even if agents_per_network is set to 1. This is because the bindings_to_add validation check will valid for both requests, due to the fact that two requests happen at the same time and the network is not hosted by any agent at that time. Then both agents (from host-a and host-b) will be sent to bind(). The root cause is the "check number of agents per network" action and "bind agents to network" action do not happen in an atomic manner. 

The fix I proposed here does a post clean up. After every agent is bound to a network, we check the number of agents hosting this network. If the number exceeds the configured number, we do a clean-up. As per Kevin's advice, the clean-up happen in concurrent requests as well, thus we need to find a way to avoid two requests deleting different dhcp agents and leaving the network with fewer agents than expected. So I add a sort by UUID to make sure the to-be-deleted agent in two requests is the same.

Could you please help me to understand the relationship between metadata_mapping and preserve_mapped_metadata?

Sure. This request came from the billing team in the organization. They had some integration in place that used an attribute that exists in all of the APIs monitored so far. However, this attribute did not exist in a newly monitored API (which is monitored via the dynamic pollster system). We then introduced the 'metadata_mapping' feature, which is an option that allows people to map a metadata field to a new name. We then had a problem, for the operation team when troubleshooting something, they are used to the original attribute value, whereas the billing people would only care for the new one. We then created this option to preserve the mapped metadata name when sending data to Gnocchi (if we choose to do so).

Let me show a concrete case. We use the following configuration to monitor load balancers. And, we had an integration that expected the name of the resouce to come from a "display_name" field. However, the "v2/lbaas/loadbalancers" API does not have such property. Therefore, we mapped the metadata "name" under a new name "display_name". We can then choose to send just the new mapped name to Gnocchi or both of them via "preserve_mapped_metadata" parameter. Did you understand its usage now?
```
- name: "dynamic.network.services.lb.loadbalancer"
  sample_type: "gauge"
  unit: "loadbalancer"
  value_attribute: "provisioning_status"
  endpoint_type: "load-balancer"
  url_path: "v2/lbaas/loadbalancers"
  metadata_fields:
    - "name"
    - "flavor_id"
    - "description"
    - "provisioning_status"
    - "vip_address"
    - "operating_status"
    - "created_at"
    - "updated_at"
  value_mapping:
    ACTIVE: "1"
  metadata_map:
    name: "display_name"
  default_value_mapping: 0

```

I was wondering however if, instead of the hash with functions have you considered creating a class hierarchy with a common API, possibly a base class with some common functionality and using a factory method that returns an instance of the correct class?

Basically the factory method replaces your hash, and unless you want to log, you don't even need a separate method to skip. With that design, your genpwd becomes (in semi-pseudo code):

  for ansible_variable_key, password in passwords.items():
    passwd_handler = PasswordFactory.build(ansible_variable_key, password)
    passwords[ansible_variable_key] = passwd_handler.generate_if_empty()

Actually I think that those unit tests would be better because they would test actual implementations of the skip/generate logic for different kinds of passwords instead of mocked.

I was looking at your unit tests and they actually only visit lines 149-152 but because you've mocked the generators and skip functions, your unit tests do not check what I think are the most important things:

- when is a new uuid token generated and when is an existing one used

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
based on IRC discussion it seems this uses a separate tranasction because it then can take advantage of the retry decorator, in case another process gets to it first, it should return the value that was just created.  OK. but can we then use the return value right here instaed of calling again down below?

also why would a "Security group" be the kind of thing subject to racing processes trying to create the same one?  seems like an administrator-level concept that would be infrequently created.

Looking through the history of commits around this, the issue was discovered while running Rally (the performance/stress testing project) which creates lots of resource concurrently, among other things. And so I think they saw issues where a racing server create "lost" and failed to the end user, because two requests were trying to create the default security group at the same time.

While the default security group is an admin-level concept, because it is "default" (i.e. supposed to exist without any intervention from an admin) and because, at the time, these were owned by nova-networking, nova was responsible for creating the default group (not the administrator). And since they are per project, I guess it makes sense that the thinking was to create the default group for a project during instance create, when it is first needed.

what is the rationale for the code here to be inside a closure?  it seems to suggest there was some some history here, however as someone who has never seen this code it's not clear why the code is organized this way, assuming im reading the gerrit correctly it looks like it is referenced on line 1806 but could just as well be inline at that point.

Good question and I'm afraid I don't know. I also find it unexpected and seems it could be inline.

(later) I looked up the commit from 2012 where this was added and there's no review comments around it, so it appears it was just a way to make things look more organized, perhaps?

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/8973/2/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py@1339
Ack, will do in the next PS and note it in the commit message.

very possible, I used to do that all the time for some reason too.   suggest breaking it out, because it contributes to the lack of clarity surrounding the security_group_ensure_default() function as well as it suggests more complex use of this code which is not in fact present.

how would this default_group have changed from when this function was called at the top of this function? would it be sufficient to just assign default_group at the top when this function was called the first time?

This is interesting and off the top of my head, I don't see why we couldn't just use the returned group from the earlier security_group_ensure_default call. And, referring back to the original commit that added this code again [1], it looks like originally this was the only place where security_group_ensure_default was called.

A second call was added later to address the case of racing server create requests (as we discussed earlier on IRC [2]):

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/122291/6/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py

and the later call of _security_group_ensure_default was not revisited and was left as-is.

Finally for completeness, the private _security_group_ensure_default method was added here, before the second security_group_ensure_default call was added:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/115255/2/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py

and the purpose of the private method was to make the _security_group_ensure_default use the current database transaction instead of creating a separate one.

Based on this analysis, it looks like this call is just residue left over from earlier refactoring and is not needed. So, I think the best thing to do is to remove this second call and use the returned group from the first call earlier.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/8973/2/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py@1339
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-10-14.log.html#t2019-10-14T16:31:51

Thanks for the fresh eyes on this. I got tunneled with how to fix this after being really confused about the duplicate record creation, putting print statements all over the place, and finally finding what was going on many hours later. xD
Note to reviewers: here is where we use a separate database transaction when getting or creating the default security group.
Heh and if this was False the _security_group_ensure_default call in the previous line was pointless.

user_id is part of the request, it's not part of any response body because it's assumed if you knew the ID well enough to make the request then you still know the ID when you get the response. A user is an inseparable part of an application credential.

secret is mentioned as part of create:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html?expanded=create-application-credential-detail#create-application-credential

It will never appear as a response to a GET, but it can be specified during create and will be displayed once as a response to create.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Could you elaborate a bit here?

If the user/project/role have been synced so they have the same name/ID in the subcloud, why is the identity sync status flipping every audit cycle?

> Could you elaborate a bit here?
 > 
 > If the user/project/role have been synced so they have the same
 > name/ID in the subcloud, why is the identity sync status flipping
 > every audit cycle?

project role assignment synchronization is still through keystone APIs (not dcdbsync) since there aren't ID to sync for assignment. At the every first audit, roles are queued for sync but the job doesn't run and their ids don't changed at the subcloud yet. At the same audit dcorch finds the project role assignment actually exist (since it check names in has_same_ids()), so it maps the the assginment of center cloud to the assignment of the subcloud with the current ids. Once the roles sync job queued get executed, roles ids are changed. At this point the assignment mappings are invalid. The next audit can no longer find the mapped assignment from subcloud so the logic falls into audit_discrepancy() where the has_same_ids() return TRUE again and a PUT job is queued for the assignment. The sync endpoint type becomes "out-of-sync" since there is a job for it. Once the PUT function return, it returns to "in-sync" again.
Makes sense.  Please add this explanation to the git commit message.

dcorch/engine/sync_services/identity.py.message: This comment no longer seems to be true?
if we're switching from names to IDs, do we need to modify this function to look at the user/role/project IDs instead of names?
Okay...please add a comment to this effect in or above this function so that the next developer to look at this doesn't get confused.

> if we're switching from names to IDs, do we need to modify this
 > function to look at the user/role/project IDs instead of names?

By names in this function is fine, since it gets called only if the mapped subcloud assignment are found by id in subcloud resources just retrieved. In another word, the ids are guaranteed to be the same by the time same_resource() are called. It's kind of redundant but it's the generic algorithm for all types of resources.
